candidates.title: Fix CI freezing
candidates.body:
In my haste to try to work on Gooey last night, I published a kludgine update without waiting for CI to finish. After both Kludgine and Gooey's CI timed out, I launched the investigation.

In the end there is a "fix" -- I think the old code (while amateurish with its usage of boxing futures and fusing, which are unnecessary here I now know) was technically more correct than what is happening here. I put in an issue for the wgpu developers to see: gfx-rs/wgpu#2266.

This also overhauls the CI workflows so that they're split. The dependencies have been switched to those that are in the wgpu repository's workflows.

candidates.title: Kludgine Redux
candidates.body:
As I've been laboring away on [PliantDb](https://github.com/khonsulabs/pliantdb/), I have been trying to figure out what I wanted to do with Kludgine. I knew I wanted to use it, but the UI code had problems. Lots of problems.

In the end, my philosophies of PliantDb I want to bleed into this project. The UI code had these main flaws that I consider untenable:

* Hard to unit test.
* Hard to debug.

Overall, I liked how the design was going, but Kludgine was a beast. And, I was having issues that would crop up in complex layouts that wouldn't be reproduced in simpler projects. 

This PR is going to kick off a rewite of the UI system, but the first task is to strip Kludgine down to its bare parts. This is going to be the core part of Kludgine: easy to use rendering primitives and basic window/input support.

The next step will be to create a separate UI crate that will build on top o this basic framework that Kludgine provides. Kludgine may become an omnibus crate and include everything all in one with a lot of feature flags. Or, it might be that you build your app by picking and choosing which crates to use. I'm not sure yet.


As a side effect, invalidates these issues: Closes #46 and #47

candidates.title: Rethinking components
candidates.body: This refactoring changes how components and styles are stored, providing a much cleaner interface and path for expansion within theming.

candidates.title: Update wgpu
candidates.body:
Upon trying to update rgx to wgpu 0.6, I ran into a lot of issues with lifetime management due to wgpu's new BufferSlice and its extra lifetime introduction. It significantly broke the renderer phase of Kludgine, but my wrestling with getting rgx compiling led me to stop aiming for compatibility.

Kludgine already wasn't using the sprite or shape pipelines, and it was using euclid for math instead of the built-in rgx types. I had a fair amount of code that was purely for converting between types. Thus, [easygpu](https://github.com/khonsulabs/easygpu) was created.

In the end, I think what I learned would allow me to backpatch rgx with the updates, but I'm honestly pretty happy with the smaller footprint of this dependency and its goals, so probably will just maintain easygpu moving forward. I toyed with inlining it and easygpu-lyon, but I opted to keep those crates more focused. Frankly, I've been tempted to split Kludgine into a few crates.

candidates.title: New shapes
candidates.body: Utilizes [rgx-lyon](https://github.com/khonsulabs/rgx-lyon) to provide tessellation. Newly exposed types now match the proper geometry types, simplifying their construction.

candidates.title: Refactoring how engine works to be more elm-like
candidates.body:
The existing rendering engine did not help in creating composable functionality. It left you up to do whatever you wanted, which in a way is OK, but when thinking about how I personally wanted to use this engine, I decided I wanted to converge the ideas of UI and the actual drawing calls. My previous attempts tried to keep everything separate, but I think the better design is to just make this engine more of a generic application engine.

Goals: 
* Components should be able to contain other components
* Components should have a message passing mechanism to communicate between each other.
* Components should be persistent, but for now rendering is still done each frame by calling Component.render()

candidates.title: Refactor GUI
candidates.body:
Refs #3 

* Get event handling working in a way that makes it easy to update UI
* Replace hand-written layout code with Stretch

chosen_pr.title: Update wgpu
chosen_pr.body:
Upon trying to update rgx to wgpu 0.6, I ran into a lot of issues with lifetime management due to wgpu's new BufferSlice and its extra lifetime introduction. It significantly broke the renderer phase of Kludgine, but my wrestling with getting rgx compiling led me to stop aiming for compatibility.

Kludgine already wasn't using the sprite or shape pipelines, and it was using euclid for math instead of the built-in rgx types. I had a fair amount of code that was purely for converting between types. Thus, [easygpu](https://github.com/khonsulabs/easygpu) was created.

In the end, I think what I learned would allow me to backpatch rgx with the updates, but I'm honestly pretty happy with the smaller footprint of this dependency and its goals, so probably will just maintain easygpu moving forward. I toyed with inlining it and easygpu-lyon, but I opted to keep those crates more focused. Frankly, I've been tempted to split Kludgine into a few crates.
